Posts.Content: Aug 2, 2012 10:55AM jlbb_1 wrote: Still getting used to this site and how to find the most recent posts to a topic. Wanted to let you know about a trick I use with my seatbelt so it doesn't rub on my port (which is on my left side). I use a black binder clip and clip it at the top of the seatbelt so it holds back the tension that would otherwise pull tight against my shoulder. If I ever get stopped by the cops, I'm pretty sure a flash of my bald head, or the port itself would get me off with a warning.
Posts.Title: Port Questions Lynn1 CelineFlower

Posts.Content: Aug 23, 2012 03:49PM jlbb_1 wrote: Like you, I was stage IV right outta the gate with mets to spine ( liver was suspicious, but eventually ruled out). The thing I had to really get my mind around was the fact that the standard is NOT to do mastectomy once the cancer has already spread. It creeps me out that this stuff will be hanging out in my breast without cutting it off. I suppose hormone treatments, etc. are supposed to keep it at bay but I'm still feeling quite new to it all so I don't know for sure.

Posts.Content: Aug 24, 2012 11:26AM - edited Aug 24, 2012 11:29AM by jlbb_1 I was diagnosed with multiple sclerosis 6 yrs before the this year's mbc from the get go at age 39, pretty sure that's rare but I'm doing by best to deal with my crappy hand just like we all are - good to have a place that's safe to vent every now and then...
Posts.Title: I thought this was supposed to be rare 4myangels carpe_diem

Posts.Content: Jul 26, 2012 02:36AM - edited Jul 26, 2012 02:38AM by jlbb_1 Thanks so much everyone (sorry for posting twice, still trying to get the hang of this site) Just had my 2nd of 4 Taxotere treatments today. Feeling ok except for the insomnia from the Dexamethasone. Once my last treatment is done on Sept. 3, the oncologist says it will be 4 weeks before all the follow up tests will have results back for us to make a decision going forward. Had to have a lung scan due to shortness of breath, and while they weren't officially looking there, I got some good news that they could see my breast tumours are shrinking and there is no longer signs of cancer in my lymph nodes. Crossing my fings that the mets in my spine are reacting the same way :) This discussion board has been a Godsend, as Googling Stage 4 breast cancer is a recipe in futility. Thanks again all!
Posts.Title: No surgery? jlbb_1 jlbb_1

Posts.Content: jlbb_1 wrote: Hi all, I am new to this board, and am wondering if anyone else was diagnosed with mets from the get go? My oncologist is now telling me it is unlikely that I will have a mastectomy when chemo is done, as the cancer has already spread. Isn't it possible that the chemo will clear up the low density stuff in my spine? Dx 3/17/2012, IDC, Right, 4cm, Stage IV, metastasized to bone/liver, 10/17 nodes, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2- Chemotherapy 4/9/2012 Adriamycin (doxorubicin), Cytoxan (cyclophosphamide), Taxotere (docetaxel) Hormonal Therapy 10/15/2012 Surgery 11/14/2012 Lymph node removal: Right, Underarm/Axillary; Mastectomy: Right Radiation Therapy 1/6/2013 Breast, Lymph nodes Hormonal Therapy 6/13/2013 Femara (letrozole) Surgery Prophylactic ovary removal Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Jul 31, 2012 01:53AM jlbb_1 wrote: Wow, you are all amazing! I remember when I was first told it was stage 4 I just wanted to find one person who was still alive with it... Grim, I know, but I needed to know it wasn't an immediate end of the line for me. I truly appreciate your willingness to share - this has been so good for me. It is going to be hard waiting for the last chemo (sept. 5) and then the four weeks that it will take for follow up tests etc. to determine next steps. I don't really know what my options may include at this point. What if there is still Ned in the nodes (since last week's scan) but some cancer remaining in the breast and vertebrae? I guess time will tell. Thanks again so much everyone :)
